(Readwise iOS)"]) Y(["Weekly Review

graph 
  subgraph main[ ]
    subgraph source["Sources"]
      subgraph padding1[ ]
          A(["Books"])
          B(["Podcasts"])
          WS(["Websites"])
          D(["Articles"])
          E(["Email Newsletters"])
          F(["Twitter Threads"])
          G(["RSS"])
          C(["YouTube"])
      end
    end

    subgraph queue["Queues"]
      subgraph padding2[ ]
        I(["Book Queue<br />(Obsidian)"])
        J(["Podcast Queue<br />(Snipd)"])
        K(["Watch Later<br />(YouTube)"])
        L(["Consumption Queue\n(Readwise Reader)"]) 
      end
    end

    subgraph consumption["Consumption"]
      subgraph padding8[ ]
        RE(["Read"])
        KRE(["Kindle Reading"])
        WA(["Watch"])
        MB(["Mobile Browse"])
        DB(["Desktop Browse"])
        J --> LI(["Listen"])
        FRSS(["Filter RSS"]) 
      end
    end

    I --> KRE
    L --> RE
    LI --> HI
    RE --> HI
    K --> WA
    WA --> T
    WS ---> MB --> V
    WS ---> DB --> HI

    subgraph curation["Curation"]
      subgraph padding3[ ]
        HI(["Text Highlights\n(Readwise)"])
        V(["Mobile Quick Capture\n(Todoist)"])
        T(["Screenshots"])
      end 
    end

    subgraph gtd["GTD"]
      subgraph padding4[ ]
        M(["Primary Inbox\n(Akiflow)"])
        AA(["Projects List\n(Obsidian)"])
      end
    end 

    subgraph pkm["PKM"]
      subgraph padding5[ ]
        Q(["PKM Sources\n(Obsidian)"])
        EE(["Create Zettles\n(Obsidian)"])
        Z(["Review, Cleanup, Expand"])
      end
    end

    subgraph reflection["Reflection"]
      subgraph padding6[ ]
        W(["Daily Highlight Review\n(Readwise iOS)"])
        Y(["Weekly Review\n(Obsidian)"])
      end
    end

    subgraph deliver["Deliver, Learn & Repeat"]
      subgraph padding7[ ]
        BB((("Share")))
        FF(["Feedback"])
      end
    end
  end

B --> J

V --> M
M --> EE
EE --> Y
Y --> AA
AA --> BB -.-> FF -.-> Z
Y --> Z

Q --> EE
Y --> Q
HI --> Q
HI --> W --> Z
G --> FRSS --> L

classDef share fill:#32DE84,stroke:#333;
classDef feedback stroke:#333;
classDef main fill:#ddd,stroke:#666,stroke-width:4px, font-weight:bold, font-size: 80px;
classDef section fill:#fff,stroke:#666,stroke-width:2px, font-weight:bold, font-size: 25px, stroke-dasharray: 5 5;
classDef padding fill:none,stroke-width:0px;


class BB share
class FF feedback
class main main
class padding1,padding2,padding3,padding4,padding5,padding6,padding7,padding8 padding
class reflection,pkm,deliver,source,queue,curation,gtd,consumption section````

item.title: Survival is not enough
item.description: Author: Seth Godin URL: https://amzn.to/3Ydw4CM “If all you do at work is hope to survive, your day can’t be much fun. We’re all working too hard. Putting in more hours than we’d like, nervous about the future, uncertain about our roles and our goals.
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Seth Godin
  • URL: https://amzn.to/3Ydw4CM

“If all you do at work is hope to survive, your day can’t be much fun. We’re all working too hard. Putting in more hours than we’d like, nervous about the future, uncertain about our roles and our goals. We work too hard to hope for mere survival. Our goal must be to thrive and prosper, not just get by.”

BKB Notes: This is an argument for setting a Daily Highlight. Be sure to make time for your prosperous work before spending all of your time just trying to put out fires. Many of these fires will put themselves out or weren’t as big of fires as they seemed at the beginning.

item.title: Traction and product development are of equal importance and should each get about half of your attention
item.description: Marketing / Traction
item.content:encoded: Marketing / Traction

item.title: Traction
item.description: Author: Gabriel Weinberg / Justin Mares URL: Surfaced through Readwise Half of my time (outside of operations) should be improving the product and the other half traction. “ Traction and product development are of equal importance and should each get about half of your attention.
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Gabriel Weinberg / Justin Mares
  • URL: Surfaced through Readwise

Half of my time (outside of operations) should be improving the product and the other half traction. “ Traction and product development are of equal importance and should each get about half of your attention. This is what we call the 50 percent rule: spend 50 percent of your time on product and 50 percent on traction.”

I should do similarly for YouTube

item.title: Paperwork complete vs Project Success
item.description: These things are sometimes at odds with each other. As a creative, you are responsible for the success of your process.
item.content:encoded:
These things are sometimes at odds with each other.

As a creative, you are responsible for the success of your process.

item.title: Happy Accidents
item.description: Many of the design decisions in our apps were a direct result of a “happy accident” we stumbled into by accidentally using the wrong setting or a quirk in the design app.
item.content:encoded: Many of the design decisions in our apps were a direct result of a “happy accident” we stumbled into by accidentally using the wrong setting or a quirk in the design app. This was and continues to be the case for me at Dorsata

item.title: Life Script
item.description: “And it is generally a script that was embedded in you from about seven or so, and then you are then perpetually living it, or trying to run away from it.
item.content:encoded: “And it is generally a script that was embedded in you from about seven or so, and then you are then perpetually living it, or trying to run away from it. And a lot of our actions, sometimes, depending on our personality traits, our historical upbringing, these can deter you from taking decisions.” — Samantha Clarke

item.title: Generalist
item.description: Being a generalist is not necessarily the easy path. It is unclear what you call yourself when people ask what you do, or what role you perform. I recently went to a Product Workshop and asked which role do you perform:
item.content:encoded:
Being a generalist is not necessarily the easy path. It is unclear what you call yourself when people ask what you do, or what role you perform. I recently went to a Product Workshop and asked which role do you perform:

  • Engineering
  • Design
  • Strategy
  • Product Management

I said all of the above.

When people ask what I am or what I do, there isn’t a clear-cut answer. I’m a designer who codes, but ultimately lives in the world of product strategy. It works fine for me because I work in a small company, but if I worked in a larger company it would probably mean picking only one of the hats to wear.

There isn’t a prescribed path for what I’m doing.

item.title: If you get asked the same thing more than three times, create a post on it
item.description: Chances are many others have the same question.
item.content:encoded: Chances are many others have the same question.

item.title: Latency
item.description: 16ms of delay is equivalent to one frame at 60 fps. Which is the target for most devices. If we are targeting 120fps, then our actions need to be completed in 8ms.
item.content:encoded:
16ms of delay is equivalent to one frame at 60 fps. Which is the target for most devices.

If we are targeting 120fps, then our actions need to be completed in 8ms.

https://input-delay.glitch.me/

A fast server response is likely 60ms+. Avoid blocking the user behind a server response if at all possible.

Source: Arc YouTube Video about Perception Break by Brian Michel

item.title: The Little Black Book of Design
item.description: Author: Adam Judge URL: https://amzn.to/3XztxCF “The people paying the bills almost always will consider properly filled-out paperwork to be more ‘successful’ than a brilliantly conceived and executed idea. Plan accordingly.
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Adam Judge
  • URL: https://amzn.to/3XztxCF

“The people paying the bills almost always will consider properly filled-out paperwork to be more ‘successful’ than a brilliantly conceived and executed idea. Plan accordingly.”

Paperwork complete vs Project Success As a creative, you are responsible for the success of your process.
